name: N'-(4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)-3-(2-methyl-1H-benzimidazol-1-yl)propanehydrazide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-637

name: N'-(4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)-3-(2-methyl-1H-benzimidazol-1-yl)propanehydrazide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-637
Reason: The target compound contains several functional groups that influence its melting point. Basic unit benzene, which is part of the compound's structure, typically has a melting point around 5.5 degrees Celsius. The compound has several substituents: -OH, -OCH3, -NH=, -CNH2, benzimidazole ring, and a hydrazide group. Each of these groups affects the melting point differently. The -OH group forms hydrogen bonds, raising the melting point significantly. The estimation for the hydroxy group is around +100 due to strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding. The -OCH3 group is an alkoxy group, which may also increase the melting point through hydrogen bonding but to a lesser extent than hydroxy, estimated as +20. The -NH= (imine) is likely to form hydrogen bonds as well, contributing roughly +50 to the melting point. The -CNH2 (primary amide) can form two hydrogen bonds, which can further increase the melting point significantly, estimated as +80. The benzimidazole ring has a pi electron system that can interact with other molecules or parts of the same molecule, raising the melting point, estimated at +30 due to the bulky and rigid structure. The hydrazide group is also capable of hydrogen bonding, which can contribute +50 to the melting point. The cumulative effect of these groups must be considered to predict the melting point.
Prediction: 5.5 (base benzene) + 100 (hydroxy group) + 20 (methoxy group) + 50 (imine group) + 80 (primary amide) + 30 (benzimidazole ring) + 50 (hydrazide group) = 230.0
